author: ZG_Brickfilms
title: It isn't Spinjitzu, but it's still cool
review:
I have always been mad at myself about never buying any of the Spinjitzu sets. I ended up buying this just to see how it was and I was surprised by what I got. The set is good. Real good. 

 

Parts

How it works is simple. The capsul that holds the minifig attaches to the vortex piece with two Technic pins. There is a specialized piece to put the vortex in to the launcher. It gets held in place by the rip chord. When you pull the rip chord, the Airjitzu flys. The faster you pull out the rip chord, the higher it will go. These really work well and can go up to 15 feet high. 

Minifigures

The minifig is nothing new. We got this version of Wrathe in other sets from the Possession line. He gets many weapons, but he can't hold them while inside the capsul.  

 

Overall opinion

I love this. It is truely hard to explain until you actually play with it. I enjoy doing tricks and other fun stunts. If you are looking for some Lego fun, buy an Airjituset, it is worth it. 

 

Note: if the flyer crashes against a hard edge, like the end of a table, it can chip.

author: Odeinoichus
title: Replacing the Spinners with Flyers.
review:
Set #70744 Airjitzu Wrayth Flyer: After so many years and after abandoning the spinners Ninjago reintroduces a new play feature. Is it handled well? This review will cover everything we can about this new element and if it succeeded in my opinion.

Packaging

A nice looking design, it’s a lot more functional than the Speedorz designs for the first year or so. It does a great job of demonstrating the function of the play gimmick and shows off everything included with the set on the front, all of the weapons and the Minifigure. Overall a very nice design, with easier access to the contents and no possibility of injuring small fingers when tearing open the plastic bubbles.

Minifigure

Wrayth: Here we have one of the ghosts that serve as the main antagonists for Year Five or Six, so many years of Ninjago I’ve understandable forgotten. The design is pretty clever, I like the dual-sided torso print with the tattered robes and chains, the use of transparent legs for the character with printed designs is also pretty ingenious to represent a spectral entity.

The facial print is dual-sided, you’ve got a single sided facial expression, but the head is completely wrapped in cloth hiding the features aside from his eyes. He’s also got a brand new head piece with a purple band around a cloaked mask to further hide his spiritual nature.

For weapons you have multiple choices. Two katana attached to the Airjitzu launcher, a pair of golden throwing stars, a jagged lime green spectral blade thing, a standard Castle era axe and a very painful looking flail on a long staff with a sai used for the tip and a piece of chain with twin Technic gears used for the head of the flail. Overall Wrayth is armed for all-out war.

The Airjitzu Flyer

This involves a very simple looking buildable element incorporating new parts that allow for the characters to pull back a rip cord and launch the Airjitzu Flyer high into the air. LEGO did a very impressive job of incorporating older toy designs into a LEGO form. Spinners of this sort are pretty forgettable, a rather bland play idea that work better for summer months, but here they’re still pretty fun.

The build looks pretty nice too, it’s a very simple build for the handle and LEGO has used them in actual sets as small tower structures, which is really a great re-use of parts. You have three basic elements, a buildable handle, the rotating lift capturing propeller piece and a small capsule to fit the Minifigure in. Overall a very nice looking design.

Overall opinion

This is a pretty decent play style element. The Airjitzu flyer works very well, provided you remember to pull the rip cord hard enough to get actual lift. It spins fairly rapidly though so being careful is a necessary precaution. The Minifigure is an added element in a cheap package to get a character you’d like. Younger fans should really enjoy pulling the rip cords to launch them into the air and trying to knock their opponent’s flyer out of some made up ring or playing area. The capsule piece looks extremely interesting and I’d suggest using them as some sort of cryogenic capsules for fans of Classic Space sets and MOCing unique elements into an impressive display.

Strongly recommended for younger builders, adults probably wouldn’t get much out of them.
